information.title: Constitutional Provisions
information.description: Part XVII of the Indian Constitution (Articles 343 to 351) deals with the official language. Initially, the Constitution recognized 14 languages, which has now increased to 22 languages in the Eighth Schedule.

information.title: Hindi and English
information.description: Article 343 declares Hindi in Devanagari script as the official language of the Union. English is also allowed to be used for official purposes. Initially, English was to be phased out by 1965, but the Official Languages Act of 1963 allowed for its continued use.

information.title: State Languages
information.description: States can adopt their own official languages through legislation. Many states have their own official languages, which may be different from Hindi.

information.title: Three-Language Formula
information.description: This educational policy recommends the study of Hindi, English, and the regional language in Hindi-speaking states, and Hindi, English, and a regional language in non-Hindi speaking states.

information.title: Classical Languages
information.description: The government has declared six languages as Classical Languages: Tamil, Sanskrit, Telugu, Kannada, Malayalam, and Odia. These languages receive special promotion and development funds.

information.title: Language of the Courts
information.description: English is the primary language used in the Supreme Court and High Courts. However, some High Courts allow the use of regional languages.
